\"Hashta b'shlucho mekadesh\".text: The full text of the sugya "hashta b'shlucho mekadesh" reads:

tokens.text:
גמ' השתא בשלוחו מקדש בו מיבעיא אמר
רב יוסף מצוה בו יותר מבשלוחו כי הא דרב
ספרא מחריך רישא רבא מלח שיבוטא
איכא דאמרי בהא איסורא נמי אית בה
כדרב יהודה אמר רב דאמר רב יהודה
אמר רב אסור לאדם שיקדש את האשה
עד שיראנה שמא יראה בה דבר מגונה
ותתגנה עליו ורחמנא אמר ואהבת לרעך
כמוך וכי איתמר דרב יוסף אסיפא איתמר
האשה מתקדשת בה ובשלוחה השתא
בשלוחה מיקדשא בה מיבעיא אמר רב יוסף
מצוה בה יותר מבשלוחה כי הא דרב ספרא
מחריך רישא רבא מלח שיבוטא אבל בהא
איסורא לית בה כדר״ל דאמר ר״ל טב
למיתב טן דו מלמיתב ארמלו:

How to know the sentence השתא בשלוחו מקד.text: How do we know that "השתא בשלוחו מקדש בו מיבעיא" is one sentence, ending with the word "מיבעיא"? Because the words after "השתא בשלוחו מקדש בו מיבעיא" are אמר ר' יוסף, "amar Rav Yosef", ie "says Rav Yosef", we see that the Gemara is introducing an opinion of R Yosef, and so by implication the Gemara's first sentence ended before the word אמר.

Where we're holding before השתא בשלוחו מ.text: , so review that Mishnah and try to guess what the Gemara might be saying about it here.

Background information that might be nec.text: It might be helpful to know that the Gemara seems to assume that Mishnayos are teaching the "biggest chiddush," ie, if a Mishnah says it is assur to steal $10, that implies that it is not assur to steal less, otherwise it would have said that instead. See how this principle applies to the

Speculate about what sort of thing the G.text: Given that there is a question on the Mishnah, it might make sense for the first sentence of the Gemara to be asking a question about it.

Literal translation of the opening kasha.text: Once we have identified which meanings to assign to the individual words, a literal (but unclear) translation of the opening kasha would be:

tokens.text: "Now that with his agent he is mekadesh, with himself is needed."

Literal translation of the opening kasha.text: Try to figure out what this might mean, then you can ask the following questions:
What does 'with his agent he is mekadesh' mean here?

tokens.text: What does 'with his agent he is mekadesh' mean here?

Literal translation of the opening kasha.targetSubtopic: What does 'with his agent he is mekadesh' mean here?
Literal translation of the opening kasha.enclosingSubtopic: Literal translation of the opening kasha
Literal translation of the opening kasha
Literal translation of the opening kasha

What does 'with his agent he is mekadesh.text: You might wonder what the words "with his agent he is mekadesh" (בשלוחו מקדש) mean. They are a reference to the Mishnah, which said that a man can be mekadesh with his agent.

What does 'with himself' mean here?.text: You might ask what does the word "with himself" (בו) means in the sentence "with himself is needed". "With himself" is a quotation from the Mishnah, and so the subject of the sentence is the word "בו", and the literal translation of the Gemara is that it is saying "the word בו in the Mishnah is needed".

What does \"is needed\" mean here?.text: The Gemara uses the phrase "is needed" (מיבעיא), from
, to speak about words in the Mishnah and to speak about why each one is necessary.

Pshat in the opening kasha.text: The opening kasha seems to be asking: now that the Mishnah has taught us that a man can be mekadesh via his agent, then I already know by implication that the lesser chiddush that he can be mekadesh himself is true, so why did the Mishnah have to teach it to me?

Ha'aras on the opening kasha.text: From the opening kasha, we see certain assumptions the Gemara is making about the Mishnah.
